journal-meta.journal-title: Human Factors: The Journal of Human Factors and Ergonomics Society

title-group.article-title: Estimating 3-D L5/S1 Moments During Manual Lifting Using a Video Coding System
title-group.subtitle: Validity and Interrater Reliability

contrib.aff: Liberty Mutual Research Institute for Safety, Hopkinton, Massachusetts
Harvard School of Public Health, Boston, Massachusetts
Harvard School of Public Health, and Brigham and Women’s Hospital, Boston, Massachusetts

author-notes.corresp: Xu Xu, Liberty Mutual Research Institute for Safety, 71 Frankland Rd., Hopkinton, MA 01748; e-mail: Xu.Xu@libertymutual.com.

article-meta.issue-title: Special Section: Keynote Addresses From the 18th Triennial Congress of the International Ergonomics Association

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: The aim of the study was to investigate the validity and interrater reliability of using a proposed video coding system to estimate the dynamical 3-D L5/S1 joint moment on the basis of four key frames from video clips of asymmetric lifting tasks.

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: L5/S1 joint loading has been widely adopted to quantify low-back loading during lifting tasks. However, the measurement of L5/S1 joint loading usually requires a laboratory environment, which cannot be applied during field surveys.

sec.title: Method:
sec.p: The validity of this system was investigated by comparing the estimated L5/S1 joint moments of various simulated lifting tasks with motion tracking system-based reference L5/S1 joint moments.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The comparison showed that the video coding system yielded good estimates on peak moment (r = .91, average absolute error [AAE] = 20.3 Nm) and cumulative moment (r = .88, AAE = 22.5 Nm·sec) of the sagittal plane. The interrater reliability of this system was assessed among 10 raters who used this system. The intraclass correlation ranged between .51 and .89 for the moments of different planes.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The results of the validity and interrater reliability analyses showed that the proposed video coding system could provide a good estimate of total L5/S1 joint loading on the basis of side-view video clips of the simulated lifting tasks.

sec.title: Application:
sec.p: Although it was not as accurate as a motion tracking system for L5/S1 joint loading calculations, this approach can be an alternative for back load estimation for some lifting configurations when the use of motion tracking systems is not possible.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Low-back pain (LBP) is prevalent in modern society. In the general population, 70% to 85% of all people experience LBP at least once in their lifetime, and it accounts for 12% of all sick days (Andersson, 1999). LBP is also one of the most costly musculoskeletal problems. The estimated cost of occupational LBP was $8,321 in 1989 and $8.8 billion in total in 1995 in the United States (Murphy & Volinn, 1999; Webster & Snook, 1994). The total cost of back pain reached $90.7 billion in 1998 (Luo, Pietrobon, Sun, Liu, & Hey, 2004).

Lifting and manual materials handling (MMH) tasks are considered to be associated with LBP (Da Costa & Vieira, 2010; Hoogendoorn et al., 2000; Kuiper et al., 1999; Schaffer, 1982). In a study involving 900 back injury cases, lifting and MMH were considered the causes of injury for 567 of them (Bigos et al., 1986). Different studies estimated that 19% to 66% of all back injuries are related to lifting tasks or MMH (National Research Council & Institute of Medicine, 2001). From the perspective of biomechanics, low-back injury happens when the load applied on a tissue exceeds the failure tolerance of the tissue (McGill, 1997). Thus, some biomechanical models were proposed to estimate the joint loadings applied on the L5/S1 joint during lifting tasks (Arjmand & Shirazi-Adl, 2005; Chaffin, 1969; Cheng & Kumar, 1991; Freivalds, Chaffin, Garg, & Lee, 1984; Genaidy, Waly, Khalil, & Hidalgo, 1993; McGill, Norman, & Cholewicki, 1996).

A widely adopted measure used to identify the risk of a lifting task and MMH is L5/S1 joint net moment. A previous study (Marras, Fine, Ferguson, & Waters, 1999) showed that the moment of external load during a lifting task has the highest odds ratio between high-risk and low-risk MMH jobs. For those studies calculating L5/S1 moment of a lifting task or MMH, some focused on the peak value (Jiang, Shin, Freeman, Reid, & Mirka, 2005; Lavender, Andersson, Schipplein, & Fuentes, 2003; Shin & Mirka, 2004), assuming the injury occurs as soon as the load exceeds the tolerance. Others (Callaghan, Salewytsch, & Andrews, 2001; de Looze, Kingma, Bussmann, & Toussaint, 1992; Hakkanen, Viikari-Juntura, & Takala, 1997) calculated the average and/or cumulative L5/S1 joint moment across the entire job, indicating that the cumulative exposure was also considered to be a risk factor of LBP (Kumar, 1990).

As L5/S1 joint moment is an important risk factor of LBP, it is necessary to have a valid and reliable method for measuring it. In a laboratory, dynamic L5/S1 joint moments are frequently calculated from the kinematics and body mass of each body segment and the external moment and force at each time instant. These data are usually obtained with the use of complicated equipment, such as opto-electronic or electromagnetic field-based motion tracking systems and force plates. The internal validity and the sensitivity of the laboratory equipment-based L5/S1 joint moments are found to be reasonably good (Kingma, de Looze, Toussaint, Klijnsma, & Bruijnen, 1996; Lariviere & Gagnon, 1998). However, since the use of laboratory equipment is not practical for field surveys, dynamic L5/S1 joint moments can be hard to examine for lifting tasks and MMH during field surveys. As a consequence, some studies have started focusing on other portable devices for measuring body movement, such as inertial measurement units (Faber, Kingma, & van Dieen, 2010) and ultrasound orientation (Marras et al., 2010), and have compared the L5/S1 moments estimated from those novel technologies with the ones estimated from the laboratory equipment. The applications of those technologies are still limited in many industrial settings, however.

A method that can be used to estimate L5/S1 joint loading during symmetric lifting tasks without depending on laboratory equipment or interfering with the tasks is a video coding system (Chang, Hsiang, Dempsey, & McGorry, 2003; Hsiang, Brogmus, Martin, & Bezverkhny, 1998). The main idea is that the lifter’s joint angular trajectory is interpolated from coder-identified major joint angles of postures in a few key frames extracted from video clips of the lifting task. These estimated joint angular trajectory data are then input into a biomechanical model (Chaffin & Anderson, 1991) for estimating the L5/S1 joint loading. Thus, only video clips of a lifting task and a coder are required for performing L5/S1 joint loading estimations. However, there are substantial limitations to this method.

First, previous research has focused only on symmetric lifting tasks, but half of field lifting tasks involve trunk lateral bending and trunk rotation (Dempsey, 2003). Simply applying a 2-D model to 3-D lifting tasks can lead to an underestimation on the L5/S1 joint moment of the sagittal plane (Kingma, de Looze, et al., 1998). To extend this video coding method to asymmetric lifting tasks, a recent study (Coenen et al., 2011) proposes a video analysis method in which a coder identifies the 3-D orientation of the trunk. Such a method could provide reasonably good estimates on peak total L5/S1 joint moments during lifting tasks. Second, a good observational method should be both valid and reliable (Bao, Howard, Spielholz, Silverstein, & Polissar, 2009; Corlett, Madeley, & Manenica, 1979). The validity and reliability of using video-based coding systems to estimate 3-D L5/S1 joint moments, however, have not been fully investigated. Third, the interpolation method used for regenerating joint angular trajectories and estimating L5/S1 joint moments in previous studies (Chang et al., 2003; Hsiang et al., 1998) was a polynomial interpolation, which has been found to be not as good as cubic spline interpolation (Xu, Chang, Faber, Kingma, & Dennerlein, 2010a).

In this study, we present a video coding system that can be used to estimate 3-D L5/S1 joint moments of 3-D lifting tasks on the basis of video clips. The main goal was to evaluate the validity and the interrater reliability of this system. Various simulated lifting tasks were performed and reference 3-D L5/S1 joint moments were obtained with the use of force plates and an opto-electronic tracking system. The video clips of these simulated tasks were input into the proposed video coding system for estimating 3-D L5/S1 joint moments. The comparison between the motion tracking system–based L5/S1 joint moments and the video coding–based L5/S1 joint moments would provide insight into the validity of this system. Interrater reliability of the video coding system was assessed among the users of this system.

sec.title: Simulated Lifting Tasks
sec.p: The kinematic data of body segments during various lifting tasks were derived in a previous study (Xu, Chang, Faber, Kingma, & Dennerlein, 2011). The experiment setup in that study is briefly described next for readers’ convenience.

sec.title: Participants (lifters)
sec.p: After signing an informed-consent form, 12 male participants (age 47.5 ±11.3 years, height 1.74 ±0.07 m, weight 84.5 ±12.7 kg) took part in the lifting task experiment. Participants with acute or chronic LBP, surgical history, or leg injuries were excluded from the experiment. The experimental protocol of the simulated lifting task was approved by the institutional review boards of Harvard School of Public Health and Liberty Mutual Research Institute for Safety.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: The lifting task consisted of picking up a crate (10 kg; width × depth × height = 39 cm × 31 cm × 22 cm) and placing it on a shelf without moving the feet. There were three lifting ranges (floor to knuckle height, floor to shoulder height, knuckle to shoulder height). Furthermore, there were three asymmetric angles of the end position relative to the starting position of the box (0°, 30° to the right, and 60° to the right). All the lifting trials started with the participants standing in front of a plastic crate. The initial horizontal distance of the crate and the lifting speed were chosen by the lifters without constraint (Figure 1). Two repetitions were performed for each lifting condition. A total of 18 lifts (3 × 3 × 2) were performed by each participant in a full-factorial design with random sequence.

caption.p: Experimental setup for the simulated lifting tasks. The regular camcorder recorded from the side view. Markers on the participants were used for monitoring the body movement. Three of 10 Eagle digital cameras that were used for the motion tracking system are shown in this picture.

sec.title: Direct measurement and reference L5/S1 moment
sec.p: Reflective markers were taped on anatomical landmarks of the lifters’ body segments, including feet, shanks, thighs, and pelvis (Cappozzo, Catani, Della Croce, & Leardini, 1995). The 3-D space positions of markers during the lifting tasks were measured by a motion tracking system (MotionAnalysis, Santa Rosa, CA) with a sampling rate of 100 Hz. The raw 3-D coordinate data were filtered with a fourth-order Butterworth low-pass filter at 8 Hz. The ground reaction force was measured with two force plates (Model 9286AA, Kistler, Switzerland) and was synchronized with the motion tracking system. Given the measured movement of body segments and the ground reaction force, the reference 3-D L5/S1 joint moment was calculated by the bottom-up method described by Kingma et al. (1996).

A digital camcorder (GR-850U, JVC, Japan) synchronized with the motion tracking system recorded the lifting task from the side view for each trial and each lifter (Figure 1) and generated 216 video clips (12 lifters × 18 lifts). Because 2 video clips were missed during the experiment, 214 video clips were used for the evaluation of the video coding system.

sec.title: Video Coding System Development
sec.p: The video coding system consisted mainly of two components. The first was the coding interface by which the raters determined the key frames from the video clip of a lifting task and estimated the major segment angles shown in the key frames. The other component was the algorithm by which the whole body movement of the lifting task was regenerated on the basis of the estimated major segment angles to calculate the L5/S1 joint moment. These two components are presented next in detail. The flowchart (Figure 2) summarizes the system.

caption.p: Flowchart of the proposed video coding method for calculating the L5/S1 moment during 3-D lifting tasks.

sec.title: Coding interface
sec.p: The coding interface has been reported in detail elsewhere (Xu et al., 2011). To familiarize the reader, we will briefly explain each step of using this interface. First, the rater retrieves a video clip of a lifting task with a customized program (Figure 3). The rater then watches the video clip and selects the frame in which the load is lifted and the frame in which the load reaches the final position. These two frames are displayed on the interface as Frame 1 and Frame 4. The interface then automatically selects Frames 2 and 3 between Frames 1 and 4 with equal time-space between them. The reason four frames are extracted from a video clip is that four key frames can effectively reconstruct the lifting trajectory and 3-D peak L5/S1 joint moments (Hsiang et al., 1998; Xu, Chang, Faber, Kingma, & Dennerlein, 2012).

caption.p: The coding interface used in the proposed video coding method. The raters used this interface to pick the key frames and estimate the major segment angles in the key frames.

sec.p: After all four frames are extracted from the video clip, the rater needs to estimate angles of seven body segments: shank, thigh, arm, forearm, trunk sagittal bending, trunk rotation, and trunk lateral bending. The validity and reliability for the observation of these segment angles were found to be acceptable (Xu et al., 2011). After the rater estimates all 28 angles (4 frames × 7 segment angles) for a video clip, the interface displays a mannequin whose posture is based on the estimated segment angles, the stature of the lifter, and the anthropometric data of the body segment lengths as a proportion of body stature (Roebuck, Kroemer, & Thomson, 1975). By comparing the lifter’s posture and the mannequin in the key frames, the rater can adjust the segment angles to better match those of the lifter in the video clips.

sec.title: Participants (raters)
sec.p: We recruited 10 raters (age 37.0 ±16.7 years) with knowledge and experience of ergonomics and/or kinesiology to test the video coding system. Each rater used the coding interface to estimate the L5/S1 joint loading for all the 214 video clips. The sequence of video clips was randomized for each rater. Before the experiment, 3 video clips were given to the raters for training. The experimental protocol for the raters was approved by the institutional review boards of Harvard School of Public Health and Liberty Mutual Research Institute for Safety.

sec.title: Estimation of L5/S1 joint moment
sec.p: The data collected from the coding interface were the frame sequence numbers in a video clip of the four key frames and the estimated seven segment angles in each of these frames. To estimate the L5/S1 joint moment, the major body segment (shank, thigh, trunk, upper arm, and forearm) lengths and weights, as well as the load weight, were necessary. The segment lengths and the load weights were directly measured, and the segment weights were derived from the body segment circumference (Zatsiorsky, 2002).

For each of the seven major segment angles, we applied a cubic spline interpolation to generate the segment angular trajectories on the basis of the frame sequence numbers of the four key frames, recording frequency of the video clip, and the estimated segment angles in the four key frames (Xu, Chang, Faber, Kingma, & Dennerlein, 2010b). The 3-D rotation matrices of shank, thigh, trunk, upper arm, and forearm at each time instant during the lifting task were then generated with Z-X-Y Euler angle sequence (transverse rotation–coronal flexion–sagittal flexion; Table 1). Since only the sagittal angles of the shank and thigh were estimated from the coder interface, the rotation matrices of these segments were actually a 2-D rotation matrix with 3-by-3 form. Although the rater also estimated only flexion angles for the arms, arm orientations were 3-D because of the asymmetry in trunk 3-D motion. The full body movements were then reconstructed with the rotation matrix of each body segment and fixed segment lengths.

caption.p: The Calculation of the 3-D Rotation Matrices of Each Major Body Segment

tr.td: Angular trajectories of trunk rotation, trunk lateral bending, and trunk sagittal bending
Angular trajectories of trunk rotation, trunk lateral bending, and upper arm
Angular trajectories of trunk rotation, trunk lateral bending, and forearm

sec.p: The estimated center of mass of each segment was determined by the anthropometric data (Dempster, 1955). The estimated position of L5/S1 was situated one fifth of the distance from hip to shoulder (Chaffin & Anderson, 1991). The flexion of the pelvis was estimated by a regression equation including trunk flexion and knee flexion (Anderson, Chaffin, & Herrin, 1986), the rotation of the pelvis was assumed to be one fourth of the trunk rotation (Kingma, van Dieen, et al., 1998), and the lateral bending of the pelvis was ignored because of its small amount (Kingma, van Dieen, et al., 1998). The moment of inertia of the trunk, upper arm, and forearm was calculated from the segment length and weight (Zatsiorsky, 2002). The external load on the hands was estimated from the load and the double differentiated position of the hand. Dynamic 3-D L5/S1 moments with respect to the local pelvis axes at each time instant were estimated by the external force exerted on the hands and the movements of the body segments above the level of L5/S1 (Kingma et al., 1996).

sec.title: Validity
sec.p: For all lifting trials and all raters, we compared the video coding system–based peak and cumulative value of L5/S1 joint moments in the coronal plane, the sagittal plane, and the rotational plane, as well as the peak and cumulative value of total L5/S1 joint moments, with those of the reference L5/S1 joint moments, respectively, by calculating correlation coefficients and absolute errors. Linear regressions were performed between the video coding system–based moments and the reference moments as well. In terms of temporal comparison, the time when video coding system–based peak moment occurred was compared with the time when the reference peak moment occurred.

sec.title: Interrater reliability
sec.p: To quantify interuser reliability of the video coding system, intraclass correlation (ICC) was calculated across the video coding system–based peak and cumulative value of L5/S1 joint moments. Since the raters in this study were randomly selected from a population of raters, ICC (2, 1) was adopted, as suggested by Shrout and Fleiss (1979). Standard deviations of video coding system–based peak and average values of L5/S1 joint moments were calculated among all the users by pooling the standard deviation across all the lifting trials to quantify interuser variability (Bao et al., 2009).

sec.title: Validity
sec.p: For most of the lifting trials, the range of video coding system–based 3-D L5/S1 joint moments was in the same range as the reference 3-D L5/S1 joint moments (Figure 4). The video coding system–based L5/S1 moment in the sagittal plane followed the trend of the reference; however, it is smoother (has fewer local minimum and maximum values) than the reference, as it is based on a cubic spline interpolation through only four key frames. Considering that the moment in the sagittal plane was dominant in the total L5/S1 moment, both the estimated and the reference total L5/S1 moments were close to the moment in the sagittal plane. The total moment was the vector summation of the L5/S1 moments of the three planes.

caption.p: An example (30° asymmetric angle with floor-to-knuckle-height lifting range) of the estimated 3-D L5/S1 moment versus reference 3-D L5/S1 moment (left). The total moment (right) was the vector summation of the L5/S1 moments of the three planes.

sec.p: For the peak and cumulative moments, the video coding method yielded a good estimate on the total L5/S1 moment and the moment in the sagittal plane (Figure 5). The correlation coefficients were greater than 0.85. Although the absolute errors in both the coronal and rotational planes seemed to be smaller than that in the sagittal plane, the absolute percentage errors in those two planes were much larger since the magnitude of the moments in these two planes was small.

caption.p: The top row shows the comparison between the reference peak 3-D L5/S1 moment and the estimated peak 3-D L5/S1 moment for all lifting tasks and all raters. The bottom row shows the comparison between the reference cumulative 3-D L5/S1 moment and the estimated cumulative L5/S1 moment. E indicates the average absolute error (AAE). The numbers in the parentheses are the AAEs in percentages with the reference moments as the reference points. Reg indicates the linear regression between the reference and estimated moments. The solid line is the linear regression line. The dashed diagonal line is the identity line.

sec.p: Because the absolute error could not indicate whether the estimate was greater than or less than the reference value, the estimation error was also calculated by subtracting the reference moment from the estimated moment. A positive and a negative estimation error indicated overestimation and underestimation, respectively. The histogram of the estimation error across all the lifting conditions for peak and cumulative 3-D L5/S1 moments showed that most of the error distributions were symmetric, bell shaped, and approximately zero centered (Figure 6). The video coding system–based peak moments occurred 0.30 ±0.57 s and 0.36 ±0.63 s before the reference peak moments for the coronal plane and the rotational plane, respectively, and occurred 0.17 ±0.42 s and 0.12 ±0.40 s after the reference peak moments for the sagittal plane and total moments.

caption.p: Histograms of the estimation error of the peak and cumulative 3-D L5/S1 moments. A p value less than .05 indicates that the deviations from zero were statistically significant.

sec.title: Reliability
sec.p: The ICC was larger than 0.5 for all the peak and cumulative values of 3-D L5/S1 joint moments except for the peak moment in the rotational plane (Table 2). For the total L5/S1 moment and the moment in the sagittal plane, their corresponding ICCs were larger than 0.8. The pooled standard deviations were less than 22 Nm for the peak moment and 26 Nm·sec for the cumulative moment. The coefficient of variation (pooled standard deviations normalized by mean value) ranged from 12% (peak moment in the sagittal plane and the peak moment of the total L5/S1 moment) to 67% (cumulative moment in the coronal plane).

caption.p: The Intraclass Correlation Coefficients (ICC) and the Pooled Standard Deviations of the 3-D L5/S1 Joint Moment Among Raters

tr.th: Pooled standard deviation divided by the mean (%)

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In the present study, a video coding system was examined for estimating 3-D L5/S1 joint loading during 3-D lifting tasks. Its validity and interrater reliability were then investigated. The correlation coefficient and linear regression indicated that the estimated peak moment and the estimated cumulative moment in the sagittal plane were positively correlated to the reference value yielded by the motion tracking system, with acceptable absolute errors. The ICC showed that when different raters used this system, the estimated 3-D L5/S1 moments showed a general agreement between the raters.

Among the estimated peak and cumulative moments of the three orthogonal planes, the ones of the sagittal plane correlated best with the reference values. Their histograms of the estimation errors indicated that the overall numbers of overestimation and underestimation were about the same. Further analysis revealed that after averaging for 18 lifts and 12 lifters, the percentage error for the peak moment in the sagittal plane ranged from −3.7% to 3.2% across raters, and after averaging for 18 lifts and 10 raters, it ranged from −15.4% to 12.6% across lifters. Analogously, the percentage error for the cumulative moment ranged from −10.0% to 23.3% across raters, which was close to the error range found in a previous study (Sutherland, Albert, Wrigley, & Callaghan, 2008) and from −9.7% to 12.0% for different lifters.

If n (n = 1, 2, . . . 10) raters were randomly selected and the averages among those raters were used as the estimated moments, the range of the percentage error for the moment would be reduced as the number of selected raters increased (Figure 7). Thus, the overall estimated peak and cumulative moment of the sagittal plane were unbiased in general, although there might be overestimation or underestimation for a specific rater or for the video clips of a specific lifter. Using an average of multiple raters could reduce the error of the estimated moments.

caption.p: Bar plot showing that the range of percentage error for the moment decreased as the number of randomly selected raters increased. The middle bar is the median, the box represents the 25th percentile and 75th percentile, and error bars represent the maximum and the minimum value.

sec.p: The estimated moments of the coronal and rotational planes were not well correlated with their references. Because the video coding system is based on only four key frames of the video clips from a single viewing angle, it is not as sensitive as the motion tracking systems on estimating the moments with small amounts of change. For the lifting tasks performed in this study, the large moment of the sagittal plane attributable to gravity and the strong upward acceleration can be estimated with the video coding system, whereas the small moments of the coronal and rotational planes cannot be estimated well. As the moments of the coronal and the rotational planes were not dominant in the total L5/S1 moment for the simulated lifting tasks, the estimation error of these two planes did not account for the majority of the estimation error of the total L5/S1 moment. In the real world, some lifting tasks may contain larger moments in the coronal plane and the rotational plane (Faber et al., 2009). Since we did not fully investigate whether the proposed video coding method could catch large moments in the coronal and rotational planes, using the current video coding method for those lifting tasks might result in a more erroneous total L5/S1 moment estimation.

Because the moments of the sagittal plane accounted for the majority of the total moment for the simulated lifting tasks, the correlation coefficients and the absolute estimated errors of the total L5/S1 moment were close to those of the moment of the sagittal plane. The absolute estimated error of the total L5/S1 moment was in the same range as shown in a previous study (Coenen et al., 2011). A further analysis was performed to see whether identifying only the trunk sagittal angle in the key frames could provide a good estimate on the total L5/S1 moment. The rater-identified trunk rotational angle and the trunk lateral bending angle were set to zero to simulate the case in which the rater would identify only the trunk sagittal angle. In this way, the regenerated body movement that was used to estimate the L5/S1 joint moment became a 2-D movement, and the total moment was the moment in the sagittal plane. The results show that identifying only the trunk sagittal angle could also provide a robust estimate on peak total moment and the cumulative total moment (Figure 8).

caption.p: Comparison between the reference and the estimated peak and cumulative total L5/S1 moments when the trunk lateral bending angle and rotational angle were not identified.

sec.p: A reason for this finding is that for most of the lifting tasks in the present study, the peak L5/S1 moment and the majority of the cumulative L5/S1 moment occurred at the beginning of the lift, when the body movement was almost symmetric and in the sagittal plane. Thus, for such lifting tasks, a 2-D video coding method (Chang et al., 2003) would be robust enough to estimate the peak and cumulative total moments. However, it should be noted that for 3-D lifting tasks with more asymmetry in the starting position, ignoring the trunk lateral bending and trunk rotation could introduce significant error in the L5/S1 joint moment (Kingma, de Looze, et al., 1998).

The ICC coefficients revealed that the proposed video coding system can provide a reliable estimate (ICC ≥ 0.8) on the total L5/S1 moment. When the raters watched the same video clip, they had a good agreement (ICC ≥ 0.8) on the estimated peak and cumulative L5/S1 moments of the sagittal plane. For the moments of the coronal and rotational planes, although the ICC coefficient did not show a strong consistency among the raters (0.4 < ICC < 0.8), the pooled standard deviations were in a limited range. This finding means that although the raters did not agree with each other for the moments of these two planes, the magnitude of their disagreement was limited. Consequently, because the raters agreed with each other on the moment of the sagittal plane, which contained the majority of the total L5/S1 moments, and the disagreement on the moments of the other two planes had a limited range, the total L5/S1 moments had a good consistency among different raters.

The error of the estimated moments mainly consisted of two parts. The first error source was the four-point cubic spline interpolation applied on the Euler segment angles. Compared with the measured angular trajectory, such interpolation yielded less than a 10° error in terms of root mean square error on the Euler segment angular trajectory (Xu et al., 2010b). When these erroneous segment angular trajectories were used to calculate the 3-D L5/S1 joint moment, the error of the 3-D L5/S1 joint moment ranged from 11 Nm to 22 Nm (Xu et al., 2012). The second error source was the raters’ perception. When the raters identified the segment angles with the interface of the proposed video coding system, the average identification error for different body segments ranged from 4.4° to 14.7° (Xu et al., 2011). These perception errors were then introduced to the segment angular trajectories during the interpolation.

A previous study (Andrews & Callaghan, 2003) indicated that the percentage error of the cumulative low-back moment was less than 3% when the video sampling rate was as low as two frames per second. In the current study, although the video sampling rate varied for each video clip since four frames were extracted for the video clips with different time lengths, the mean video sampling rate was 2.30 ±0.46 frames per second, which is comparable to the sampling rate in that previous study. However, the percentage error of the cumulative L5/S1 moment in the current study was 17%, which is much larger than the percentage error found previously. This finding could be attributable to the two different reference moments adopted by the two studies. Whereas the previous study used a video-based 2-D static biomechanical model as the reference moment, the current study used a tracking system–based 3-D dynamic biomechanical model. The difference between the two references needs to be further investigated.

In addition, the lifting cycle started from the initial upright standing posture in the previous study, whereas it started from liftoff in the current study. Since the overestimation and underestimation tended to cancel each other out across the lifting tasks in Callaghan and Andrews (2003), a shorter lifting cycle in the current study may have inflated the percentage error of the cumulative total L5/S1 moment.

It should be noticed that the validity and the reliability of the proposed video coding system were examined with only limited and well-controlled lifting tasks in the present study. These laboratory lifting tasks were within a confined range, starting from a symmetric lifting origin without foot movement, and represented a limited lifting range with limited dynamic variability. The validity and reliability could be altered when using this video coding method for real-world lifting tasks with a free movement of the body. For example, in many industry jobs, the lifters move their feet during lifting tasks. Although the body movement with respect to feet could still be regenerated, such body movement would be in a noninertial frame of reference, and fictitious force would need to be considered during the L5/S1 moment calculation. As the lifting speed was chosen by the lifters, only a slight to moderate dynamic component was contained in the total L5/S1 moment. It is still questionable whether this video coding system can provide a good estimate for the lifting tasks with fast lifting speeds, since the algorithm of body movement regeneration and the sampling speed of a conventional camera may be not suitable for fast movement. To generalize the current results, more lifting configurations need to be performed for evaluating the proposed video coding system.

There were a few other limitations to this study that need to be addressed. First, only raters with ergonomics or kinesiology backgrounds were recruited for the segment angle identification. It is unclear whether the results can be generalized to an inexperienced population. Second, unlike 3DSSPP (University of Michigan 3D Static Strength Predication Program), which allows the raters to input 3-D joint angles for shoulder and hip joint, the current video coding system did not consider the upper-arm and thigh abduction angles. Upper-arm abduction can lead to a shortened moment arm of the load, and thigh abduction can alter the perceived segment angles of lower extremities. Identifying the upper-arm and thigh segment angles in 3-D, however, could be challenging (Krosshaug et al., 2007; Lu, Waters, Werren, & Piacitelli, 2011). Third, markers attached on the lifters may help the rater to identify the center of the joints. In a video clip of a real-world job, the clothes a lifter wears may make it harder to determine the positions of the center of the joints. All these limitations should be further investigated in future research.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The results of the validity and interrater reliability analyses show that the proposed video coding system could provide a relatively good estimate of total L5/S1 joint loading on the basis of side-view video clips of simulated lifting tasks. Although the system was not as accurate as a motion tracking system for L5/S1 joint loading calculations, it can be an alternative for back-load estimation of some lifting tasks when the use of a motion tracking system is not practical.

list-item.p: The proposed video coding system could provide a good estimate of total L5/S1 joint moment on the basis of side-view video clips of some lifting tasks.
The estimated total L5/S1 joint moment was consistent among different raters.
The system is an alternative for L5/S1 joint moment estimation of some lifting configurations when use of a motion tracking system is not practical.

bio.p: Xu Xu is a research scientist at the Liberty Mutual Research Institute for Safety. He obtained his PhD in industrial engineering from North Carolina State University in 2008.
Chien-Chi Chang is a research scientist at the Liberty Mutual Research Institute for Safety. He obtained his PhD in mechanical engineering from University of Utah in 1997.
Gert S. Faber is a postdoctoral research fellow in Harvard School of Public Health. He obtained his PhD degree from Department of Human Movement Sciences at the VU University at Amsterdam in 2010.
Idsart Kingma is an assistant professor in the Faculty of Human Movement Sciences of the VU University at Amsterdam. He obtained his PhD from VU University in 1999.

Jack T. Dennerlein is an associate professor of orthopaedic surgery at Brigham and Women’s Hospital, Harvard Medical School, and a senior lecturer in the Department of Environmental Health, Harvard School of Public Health. He obtained his PhD degree from the University of California at Berkeley in 1996.
